--- title: "Movie budgets and revenues" editor: visual --- ::: callout-important This application exercise is a demo only. You do not have a corresponding repository for it and you're not expected to turn in anything for it. ::: We will look at the relationship between budget and revenue for movies made in the United States in 1986 to 2020. The dataset is created based on data from the [Internet Movie Database (IMDB)](https://www.imdb.com/). ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) # for data analysis and visualisation library(scales) # for pretty axis labels library(DT) # for interactive table ``` ::: ## Data The `movies` data set includes basic information about each movie including budget, genre, movie studio, director, etc. A full list of the variables may be found [here](https://github.com/danielgrijalva/movie-stats). ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} movies <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/danielgrijalva/movie-stats/master/movies.csv") ``` ::: View the first 10 rows of data. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} movies ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 7,668 × 15 name rating genre year relea…¹ score votes direc…² writer star country 1 The Shi… R Drama 1980 June 1… 8.4 9.27e5 Stanle… Steph… Jack… United… 2 The Blu… R Adve… 1980 July 2… 5.8 6.5 e4 Randal… Henry… Broo… United… 3 Star Wa… PG Acti… 1980 June 2… 8.7 1.2 e6 Irvin … Leigh… Mark… United… 4 Airplan… PG Come… 1980 July 2… 7.7 2.21e5 Jim Ab… Jim A… Robe… United… 5 Caddysh… R Come… 1980 July 2… 7.3 1.08e5 Harold… Brian… Chev… United… 6 Friday … R Horr… 1980 May 9,… 6.4 1.23e5 Sean S… Victo… Bets… United… 7 The Blu… R Acti… 1980 June 2… 7.9 1.88e5 John L… Dan A… John… United… 8 Raging … R Biog… 1980 Decemb… 8.2 3.3 e5 Martin… Jake … Robe… United… 9 Superma… PG Acti… 1980 June 1… 6.8 1.01e5 Richar… Jerry… Gene… United… 10 The Lon… R Biog… 1980 May 16… 7 1 e4 Walter… Bill … Davi… United… # … with 7,658 more rows, 4 more variables: budget , gross , # company , runtime , and abbreviated variable names ¹​released, # ²​director ``` ::: ::: The \_\_\_ dataset has \_\_\_ observations and \_\_\_ variables. ## Analysis ### Gross over time We begin by looking at how the average gross revenue (`gross`) has changed over time. Since we want to visualize the results, we will choose a few genres of interest for the analysis. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} genre_list <- c("Comedy", "Action", "Animation", "Horror") ``` ::: Then, we will filter for these genres and visualize the average gross revenue over time. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} movies %>% filter(genre %in% genre_list) %>% group_by(genre,year) %>% summarise(avg_gross = mean(gross)) %>% ggplot(mapping = aes(x = year, y = avg_gross, color= genre)) + geom_point() + geom_line() + scale_color_viridis_d() + scale_y_continuous(labels = label_dollar()) + labs( x = "Year", y = "Average Gross Revenue (US Dollars)", color = "Genre", title = "Gross Revenue Over Time" ) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` `summarise()` has grouped output by 'genre'. You can override using the `.groups` argument. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Removed 47 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`). ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Removed 23 rows containing missing values (`geom_line()`). ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](ae-0-movies_files/figure-html/plot-rating-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: The plot suggests ... ### Budget and gross Next, let's see the relationship between a movie's budget and its gross revenue. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} movies %>% filter(genre %in% genre_list, budget > 0) %>% ggplot(mapping = aes(x=log(budget), y = log(gross), color=genre)) + geom_point(alpha = 0.6) + geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) + facet_wrap(~ genre) + scale_color_viridis_d() + labs( x = "Log-transformed Budget", y = "Log-transformed Gross Revenue" ) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x' ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Removed 35 rows containing non-finite values (`stat_smooth()`). ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Removed 35 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`). ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](ae-0-movies_files/figure-html/plot-revenue-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Exercises 1. Suppose we fit a regression model for each genre that uses budget to predict gross revenue. What are the signs of the correlation between `budget` and `gross` and the slope in each regression equation? 2. Suppose we fit the regression model from the previous question. Which genre would you expect to have the smallest residuals, on average (*residual = observed revenue - predicted revenue*)? 3. In the remaining time, discuss the following: Notice in the graph above that `budget` and `gross` are log-transformed. Why are the log-transformed values of the variables displayed rather than the original values (in U.S. dollars)? ## Appendix Below is a list of genres in the data set: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} movies %>% distinct(genre) %>% arrange(genre) %>% datatable() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
